explanation:
For checking MISRA C rule about string.h functions (no out‑of‑bounds accesses), the analyzer needs the following additional symbols and why:

- MHD_connection_handle_write
  - This is the caller that prepares and passes the header/body pointers and their sizes into MHD_send_hdr_and_body_. To determine if the sizes correspond to the actual object bounds you must inspect how these buffers are constructed/allocated and how header_size/body_size are computed.

- try_ready_normal_body
  - One of the routines that prepares reply bodies; it may allocate or fill the body buffer and set its size. Inspecting it is necessary to verify that body_size does not exceed the allocated buffer and to see if string.h functions are used there.

- MHD_send_data_
  - This helper is invoked from multiple branches in the target function and may itself manipulate memory or call string.h functions (memcpy/memmove/memset/strlen/etc.). Its implementation must be examined for potential OOB accesses and to understand interactions with the header/body buffers and size limits.

- MHD_send_sendfile_
  - An alternative send path (sendfile). Even though it uses files, the surrounding logic and callers may intermix memory buffers and affect when/how header/body buffers are built. Also needed to see if the same caller logic that leads to MHD_send_hdr_and_body_ is used elsewhere.

- MHD_send_iovec_ and send_iov_nontls
  - These handle iovec-style sends and are involved in preparing vectors of memory buffers. They may call or emulate string.h functions or set up iovec lengths; their implementations must be checked to ensure iovec lengths do not refer past buffer boundaries.

- pre_send_setopt and post_send_setopt
  - Called before/after vector sends. Implementations might use memset/memcpy or other string.h functions to set up or clean state; they are invoked conditionally and could touch the same buffers or related state.

- MHD_DLOG
  - post_send_setopt calls MHD_DLOG per the static graph. Logging helpers sometimes format strings or copy buffers; inspect for string.h usage that could read past buffers referenced by header/body or related metadata.

- _MHD_DROP_CONST
  - Macro used to cast away const when placing header/body into vectors. Understanding its definition is necessary to ensure the cast does not hide constness-related bugs and to see if it performs any other transformation relevant to bounds (e.g., pointer arithmetic macros).

- SSIZE_MAX and UINT_MAX
  - These limits are used to truncate/limit header_size and body_size. To verify the truncation logic avoids OOB accesses and fits the returned ssize_t semantics, the exact numeric limits and their types must be known.

- _MHD_SEND_VEC_MAX and MHD_SCKT_SEND_MAX_SIZE_
  - Used to enforce per-vector/send limits. Their values are essential to determine whether header_size+body_size will be truncated and whether the code paths that use writev/sendmsg/WSASend may attempt to reference more bytes than the actual buffers contain.

- MHD_VECT_SEND, HAVE_SENDMSG, HAVE_WRITEV, _WIN32
  - These compile-time flags select the code path (vector send vs scalar single-send). You must know which path is active to analyze actual accesses (e.g., whether iovec entries are created and passed to OS calls or whether MHD_send_data_ is used), and to inspect only the relevant implementations for string.h usage.

- struct MHD_Connection (definition)
  - The function reads many fields (socket_fd, state, sk_nonblck, daemon->options, sigpipe_blocked, sk_spipe_suppress, epoll_state, rp.resp_sender). The definition (types/bitfields) is needed to ensure no implicit truncation/overflow in size computations and to understand any ownership/lifetime rules for header/body buffers stored in the connection or related structures.

Rationale summary: The MISRA rule targets uses of standard string functions that can access past object bounds. To decide whether MHD_send_hdr_and_body_ can lead to such an out‑of‑bounds access you must (1) locate all places that create or mutate the header/body buffers and their sizes (callers and preparers), (2) inspect all callee functions that could manipulate those buffers or call string.h functions (MHD_send_data_, iovec/send helpers, pre/post send helpers), (3) know the compile‑time path that selects vector vs non‑vector code so you inspect the correct code, and (4) know the numeric limits/macros used for truncation so you can reason formally about whether pointer+length uses stay within allocated buffer sizes. The listed symbols are the minimal set required to perform that analysis.
